Award.AwardTitle: Energy Resolved Studies of Dynamics, Reactivity and Mechanism at the Gas-Surface Interface
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project supported by the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanisms Program of the Division of Chemistry, Prof. Arthur Utz of Tufts University will study how the motions (dynamics) of atoms and molecules can promote chemical reactivity at the gas-surface interface. Gas-surface reactions underlie industrial processes ranging from heterogeneous catalysis to materials deposition and semiconductor fabrication. The proposed studies will combine quantum state-resolved laser excitation of a gas phase reagent with ultra-high vacuum surface science techniques to show how specific molecular motions (bond stretches, bends, and surface vibrations) promote reactivity. Another line of inquiry will explore the rates and pathways for energy redistribution processes that dictate reactivity. The experiments will reveal how vibrational energy in the gas-phase reagent and in the surface impact reactivity. The study of surface vibrations will be a particularly significant focus as it has the potential to inform our understanding of the unique catalytic activity of nanoparticles. The ultimate goal of this work is to develop a better understanding of the important variables that influence gas-surface reactivity, with an aim towards designing better theories, identifying new strategies for chemical control, and revealing new practical applications. The results of this study will provide theorists with much useful data to test the latest theories.

The results of this research will also provide important guidance in designing practical catalytic reaction schemes, which are important to industry. Students and postdoctoral research associates who participate in this research acquire new knowledge and skills in preparation for advanced studies or entrance into the scientific/technological job market. The PI will also guide departmental efforts to incorporate active citizenship into the undergraduate and graduate curriculum at Tufts. These efforts will better prepare Tufts students engage in public discourse, participate in outreach activities, and incorporate the principles of active citizenship in their professional careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this NSF sponsored research is to gain new atomic and molecular level insight into the mechanism for methane dissociation on catalytically active metal surfaces. This reaction is the rate-limiting step in the industrial steam reforming reaction, in which naturally abundant methane (from natural gas) and water react on a metallic Ni catalyst to produce molecular hydrogen (a potential “green” fuel and a chemical reagent used in large scale to make most of the world's fertilizer) and the CO feedstock used to produce other useful chemical commodities. An accurate and detailed mechanistic understanding of this reaction is an essential component of efforts to systematically design new catalysts with improved efficiency and selectivity.

Our experiments use an infrared laser to excite specific vibrational motions of the methane reagent (C-H bond stretches and bends) in a supersonic molecular beam. These molecules, with their well-defined and tunable speed and vibrational excitation then collide with a well-characterized Ni surface, which mimics the metal catalyst. The resulting data allow us to understand how specific motions of the atoms in the methane molecule and the surface facilitate the conversion of methane into the surface bound methyl and H atoms. This experimental approach also provides quantitative measures of the reaction probability for methane with a very well defined total energy, and serves as the most stringent benchmark for theoretical calculations that simulate reactions on catalytically active metals. 

Experiments performed and supported by this award revealed the following: 1) the nature of the bending vibration has a significant effect on its ability to activate reaction. The ν2 bending mode is significantly less effective at promoting reaction than is the ν4 bending mode. This finding further supports the our model for mode- and bond selective chemistry on surfaces, which identifies unifying themes in molecular energy flow and reactivity in the gas phase, in liquids, and on surfaces.  2) Vibrationally excited molecules can physically adsorb on the surface and subsequently use their internal energy to activate their dissociation. This result establishes the importance of a new mechanism that is likely operative in industrial steam reforming reactions: methane activation via vibrationally hot precursor molecules. 3) Computational groups test the validity of their methods by exploring how the chemical identity of the surface influences reactivity. We obtained new quantitative measurements of CH4 dissociation on Ir(111) and Ir(110) (1x2) surfaces to benchmark that work. 4) We began a comparative study of the reactivity of the deuterated methane molecule, CH2D2 in the symmetric and antisymmetric C-H stretching states to better understand how the vibrational state we prepare with laser excitation might change as the incident methane molecule begins to interact with the surface prior to reaction. 5) Surface temperature dependent studies have identified the central role that vibrations of the surface metal atoms can affect reactivity (See Fig. 1). At the incident translational energies most prevalent under industrial steam reforming conditions, the vibrational motion of surface atoms can change reaction probability by three or more orders of magnitude. Collaboration with the Jackson Group at UMass-Amherst identified the mechanistic origin of this effect and their calculations quantitatively reproduced our experimental results.
